desc.content: Leonard Abrams is a writer for print as well as a filmmaker, and an editor of both. He published and edited the East Village Eye magazine from 1979 to 1987, created the multiracial hip hop club Hotel Amazon in 1988, and since then was Music Editor of Details magazine [NY] and US Editor of Soul Underground [London] and Masthead literary magazine [Melbourne]. He began traveling in Brazil in the early 1990s and started this, his first major filmmaking effort, in 2001. His transition to motion picture media comes from a desire "to tell stories in a more direct fashion, more like the original storytellers did."FilmographyQuilombo Country (2006) is the director's first film.

Alan Barnard is Professor of the Anthropology of Southern Africa at the University of Edinburgh, where he has taught since 1978. Alan has worked with Bushmen or San and on the history of San studies since the early 1970s. His ethnographic fieldwork has been mainly with the Naro Bushmen in Botswana, and also with the Khoekhoe and other populations in Botswana, Namibia and South Africa.Alan has written some seventy articles and eight books, and his work has been translated into more than ten languages. His books on Bushman peoples include an ethnographic survey, Hunters and Herders of Southern Africa: A Comparative Ethnography of the Khoisan Peoples (Cambridge University Press, 1992), a children's book, Kalahari Bushmen (Wayland, 1996), and a history of San studies, Anthropology and the Bushman (Berg, 2007). His edited works include Hunter-Gatherers in History, Archaeology and Anthropology (Berg, 2004) and five other collections.He is currently working on the coevolution of language and kinship and other areas of overlap between linguistics, archaeology, history and social anthropology. In 2007 he was commissioned by Namibia's Minister of Foreign Affairs to serve as Honorary Consul of the Republic of Namibia for Scotland. His special interest is in setting up links between Namibian and Scottish educational institutions of all kinds.

Cresantia Frances Koya was born and raised in Fiji. She is of mixed ethic-background including Irish, Samoan, Indian and Arabia with a bit of Solomon and Fijian in the mix. Although her work prioritizes scholarly writing and research, she has been involved in a number of art mediums from a young age including fashion design, drawing, painting, and writing. A member of the Niu Waves writer's collective, her first collection of poetry; "of schizophrenic voices" was published by the Pacific Writing Forum in 2002. She also founded Post-Script Writers' group for secondary school students which was housed at the Alliance Francaise in Suva, 2000-2001. After completing her Master of Arts in Education in 2002, she focused on scholarly pursuits. She is currently working towards a number of projects including a compilation of her mother's stories, poetry and photographs in collaboration with her nice Marie. She is also working on a number of project including the Fiji Emerging Women Writers project and Wasawasa: Festival of Oceans 2008 in conjunction with Kalamwasa: Festival of Writing 2009; and the Mama Hanua Project 2008-2010. She attended the Pacific Arts Festival in Pago pago this year as contemporary writer in the Fiji Delegation.

Recipient of the 2011 Nobel Peace PrizeLiberian peace and women's rights activist Leymah Gbowee is the Newsweek Daily Beast's Africa columnist. As war ravaged Liberia, Leymah Gbowee realized it is women who bear the greatest burden in prolonged conflicts. She began organizing Christian and Muslim women to demonstrate together, founding Liberian Mass Action for Peace and launching protests and a sex strike. Gbowee's part in helping to oust Charles Taylor was featured in the documentary Pray the Devil Back to Hell. Gbowee is a single mother of six, including one adopted daughter, and is based in Accra, Ghana, where she is the executive director of the Women Peace and Security Network (WIPSEN-Africa).Leymah Gbowee has spoken publically numerous times on the issue of women in conflict situations. She was a panelist at several regional and international conferences, including UNIFEM's "Women and the Disarmament, Demobilization, Reintegration and Repatriation (DDRR) Process," and the United Nations Security Council's Arria Formula Meeting on women, peace, and security. In October 2007, the Women's Leadership Board at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government honored Ms. Gbowee with the Blue Ribbon Peace Award. This annual award is given to individuals and organizations that have made a significant contribution to peace-building through innovative strategies that promote women's leadership in peace processes on the local, national, or international level. Other honors include:Recipient of the 2011 Nobel Peace PrizeRecipient of the 2010 John Jay Medal for Justice from the John Jay College of Criminal JusticeRecipient of the 2009 Gruber Prize for Women's RightsRecipient of the 2009 John F. Kennedy Profile in Courage AwardRecipient of the Women's eNews 2008 Leaders for the 21st Century Award

Hoda Hussein est ne au Caire en 1972, d'une mere alexandrine et d'un pere d'originr nubien, cette dualite de culture entre "mediterrane" et "minorite" n'etait pas la seule dualite qu'elle a du resoudre dans son esprit; maison egyptienne musilmane mais ecole francaise catholique, ne dans la capitale mais dans une ile entouree par le nile de tous les cotes, une ile poutrant qui se situe pas loin du centre ville du Caire ou ont lieu toutes les actions et activitees culturelles, artistiques et meme politiques.. etc, dans ce contexte charge de dualite extreme, hoda Hussein a adopte le concepte de la mirroire ou le "Meme" est "l'oppose", ou l'autre egale le soi meme dans un certain point, de cette energie du mirroir, ses texts sont nourris.Hoda Hussein est poetesse, romanciere et traductrice. Elle a egalement publie des short stories dans des revues arabes specialisees, elle a effectue et projete des films courts, maintemeant elle est entrain de preparer son premier exhibition d'art plastique qui aura lieu en septembre 2007.Elle est aussi nomee comme ambassadrice universelle de paix, par le cercle des ambassadeur universel de paix, association qui travaille sous la loi de unesco, member du movement "poetas del mundo" en Chile, respensable de l'unite de traduction et publication au centre egyptien pour la liberte de cretivite (ngo)Elle participle aux "voix de la mediterranee" en1999 et 2007. en 2004 et 2006, au premier et deuxieme festival de la poesie arabe a Yemen. En 2006 aussi au "Mareille/alexandrie export import" rencontre de poesie et traduction menee par le centre international de poesie a Marseille, et elle a represente l'Egypte au deuxieme festivale des poetes du monde en Chile, ou elle a recue le prix Pablo nerude pour la meilleur participation poetique et representation du patrimoine.En 2007 elle a represente le nord de l'afrique au festival international de poesie a Havana, Cuba.Bibliographie:1994: traduction: "Aitres" Christine Pont. "WORLD FESTIVAL CULTURAL ENTRE 7 hasta 12 jul 2011 HUNGRÃA"Le but du festival est de reunir ensemble tous les groupes de nations, groupes individuels, organisations d'etudiants afin qu'ils montrent l'heritage culturel de leur nation ainsi que de faire la promotion des cultures et des traditions de tous les pays au monde grace a la danse, a la musique folk. Ce festival renforcera les contacts internationaux ainsi que la conscience culturelle, creant ainsi des relations de cooperation amicales entres les differents ensembles culturels au monde.Ce festival comporte egalement une competition pour ceux qui desirent faire performer leurs danseurs professionnels ainsi que d'autres qui souhaitent seulement montrer leur heritage culturel. Dans ce festival, tout le monde peut participer: groupes vocales, soloistes, chorales academiques et de folk, danse moderne, orchestre, groupes et ensemble folk, etc. le festival est une rencontre culturelle pour l'appreciation et la promotion culturelle et touristique de la region, une occasion pour examiner de pres les nouvelles cultures afin de mieux comprendre nos differences et de creer ainsi des collaborations et amities internationales.Le festival sert de plateforme a la promotion et la popularization de l'art moderne. Nos taches fondamentales sont de promouvoir et d'integrer l'art contemporain sur la scene artisitique internationale, de faire la collection puis de disseminer l'art contemporain, de meme que de creer un environnement de pensee critique stimulant ainsi les echanges entre l'art et la societe.Chaque leader de chaque groupe doit faire une introduction de leur nation et de l'heritage culturelle suivie de leur hymne nationale, de parade dans les rues et de danse que le public pourra observer, chaque ensemble etant cense pratiquer de dix a trente minutes sur scene.Les participants auront l'occasion de visiter les lieux historiques de la ville. Les participants apprecieront l'hospitalite du lieu ou ils se trouvent.

Mazisi Raymond Fakazi Mngoni Kunene was born in Durban on 12 May 1930. He grew up in AmaHlongwa on the KwaZulu-Natal South Coast, where he attended primary school. He later attended Marianhill where he matriculated and Maphumulo Teachers Training College where he obtained certification, and then to the University of Natal where he graduated with a Masters Degree.Kunene went into exile in 1959 and in 1962 was appointed the Chief Representative of the African National Congress in Europe and America. He played a pivotal role in the founding of the anti-apartheid movement in Britain. He also worked closely with leading ANC figures, including Moses Mabhida, Oliver Tambo and Robert Resha. After establishing the South African Exhibition Appeal in 1972, to raise funds for the ANC, Professor Kunene received resounding support from renowned figures of the art world including Picasso, Chagall, Giacometti and Rauschenberg. He also served as a Cultural Advisor to UNESCO.While out of South Africa, he studied further, and lectured at a number of universities. He then taught for 19 years at the University of California in Los Angeles, where he was awarded a professorship in IsiZulu. The former University of Natal bestowed an honorary doctorate on Prof Kunene in recognition of his contribution to creative writing. Professor Kunene's literary output in exile included the published epics: Anthem of the Decades and Emperor Shaka the Great as well as two further poetry anthologies The Ancestors and the Sacred Mountain and Zulu Poems. In 1969, Kunene wrote an introductory essay to John Berger and Ann Bostock's translation of Aime Cesaire's Return to my Native Land.Upon his return to South Africa in 1993, UNESCO honoured him with the title of Africa's Poet Laureate. He published books in Zulu including Isibusiso sikamhawu (1994), Indida yamancasakazi (1995), Umzwilili wama-Afrika (1996) and Igudu likaSomcabeko (1997). In 2005, the Minister of Arts and Culture Pallo Jordan, honoured him as South Africa's first Poet Laureate. Mazisi Kunene passed away on 11 August 2006 and is survived by his wife, Mathabo Kunene, daughter Lamakhosi and sons Zosukuma, Ra and Rre.MAZISI KUNENE FOUNDATIONThe Mazisi Kunene Foundation Trust was launched on 3 June 2006. Its primary mission is to preserve and promote a cultural literary archive of African writing with the works of renowned South Africa's first Poet Laureate, Mazisi Kunene at its nucleus.This involves translation, publication and distribution of Mazisi Kunene's work as well as identifying other neglected historical and new African writers for the purposes of publication and collection.This bold and visionary initiative is in understanding that preserving the South African legacy is a responsibility of all South Africans.
